The dragon doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

items.name: Mimicry
entries: Impersonating characters or their allies could be a fun trick for a crafty dragon.
The dragon can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

items.name: Rejuvenation
entries: You might decide that dragons in your campaign, being an essential part of the Material Plane, are nearly impossible to destroy. A dragon's life essence might be preserved in the egg from which it first emerged, in its hoard, or in a cavernous hall at the center of the world, just as a lich's essence is hidden in a phylactery.

If it has an essence-preserving object, a destroyed dragon gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the object.

items.name: Special Senses
entries: Most dragons have {@sense blindsight} and {@sense darkvision}. You might upgrade {@sense blindsight} to {@sense truesight}, or you could give a dragon with a burrowing speed {@sense tremorsense}.

fluff.name: Adult Red Dragon

entries: The most covetous of the true dragons, red dragons tirelessly seek to increase their treasure hoards. They are exceptionally vain, even for dragons, and their conceit is reflected in their proud bearing and their disdain for other creatures. The odor of sulfur and pumice surrounds a red dragon, whose swept-back horns and spinal frill define its silhouette. Its beaked snout vents smoke at all times, and its eyes dance with flame when it is angry. Its wings are the longest of any chromatic dragon, and have a blue-black tint along the trailing edge that resembles metal burned blue by fire.

The scales of a red dragon wyrmling are a bright glossy scarlet, turning a dull, deeper red and becoming as thick and strong as metal as the dragon ages. Its pupils also fade as it ages, and the oldest red dragons have eyes that resemble molten lava orbs.

entries.name: Mountain Masters
entries: Red dragons prefer mountainous terrain, badlands, and any other locale where they can perch high and survey their domain. Their preference for mountains brings them into conflict with the hill-dwelling copper dragons from time to time.

entries.name: Arrogant Tyrants
entries: Red dragons fly into destructive rages and act on impulse when angered. They are so ferocious and vengeful that they are regarded as the archetypical evil dragon by many cultures.

No other dragon comes close to the arrogance of the red dragon. These creatures see themselves as kings and emperors, and view the rest of dragonkind as inferior. Believing that they are chosen by Tiamat to rule in her name, red dragons consider the world and every creature in it as theirs to command.

entries.name: Status and Slaves
entries: Red dragons are fiercely territorial and isolationist. However, they yearn to know about events in the wider world, and they make use of lesser creatures as informants, messengers, and spies. They are most interested in news about other red dragons, with which they compete constantly for status.

When it requires servants, a red dragon demands fealty from chaotic evil humanoids. If allegiance isn't forthcoming, it slaughters a tribe's leaders and claims lordship over the survivors. Creatures serving a red dragon live in constant terror of being roasted and eaten for displeasing it. They spend most of their time fawning over the creature in an attempt to stay alive.

entries.name: Obsessive Collectors
entries: Red dragons value wealth above all else, and their treasure hoards are legendary. They covet anything of monetary value, and can often judge the worth of a bauble to within a copper piece at a glance. A red dragon has a special affection for treasure claimed from powerful enemies it has slain, exhibiting that treasure to prove its superiority.

A red dragon knows the value and provenance of every item in its hoard, along with each item's exact location. It might notice the absence of a single coin, igniting its rage as it tracks down and slays the thief without mercy. If the thief can't be found, the dragon goes on a rampage, laying waste to towns and villages in an attempt to sate its wrath.

entries.name: A Red Dragon's Lair
entries: Red dragons lair in high mountains or hills, dwelling in caverns under snow-capped peaks, or within the deep halls of abandoned mines and dwarven strongholds. Caves with volcanic or geothermal activity are the most highly prized red dragon lairs, creating hazards that hinder intruders and letting searing heat and volcanic gases wash over a dragon as it sleeps. With its hoard well protected deep within the lair, a red dragon spends as much of its time outside the mountain as in it. For a red dragon, the great heights of the world are the throne from which it can look out to survey all it controls-and the wider world it seeks to control.
Throughout the lair complex, servants erect monuments to the dragon's power, telling the grim story of its life, the enemies it has slain, and the nations it has conquered.

entries.name: Chromatic Dragons
entries: The black, blue, green, red, and white dragons represent the evil side of dragonkind. Aggressive, gluttonous, and vain, chromatic dragons are dark sages and powerful tyrants feared by all creatures-including each other.

entries.name: Driven by Greed
entries: Chromatic dragons lust after treasure, and this greed colors their every scheme and plot. They believe that the world's wealth belongs to them by right, and a chromatic dragon seizes that wealth without regard for the humanoids and other creatures that have "stolen" it. With its piles of coins, gleaming gems, and magic items, a dragon's hoard is the stuff of legend. However, chromatic dragons have no interest in commerce, amassing wealth for no other reason than to have it.

entries.name: Creatures of Ego
entries: Chromatic dragons are united by their sense of superiority, believing themselves the most powerful and worthy of all mortal creatures. When they interact with other creatures, it is only to further their own interests. They believe in their innate right to rule, and this belief is the cornerstone of every chromatic dragon's personality and worldview. Trying to humble a chromatic dragon is like trying to convince the wind to stop blowing. To these creatures, humanoids are animals, fit to serve as prey or beasts of burden, and wholly unworthy of respect.

entries.name: Dangerous Lairs
entries: A dragon's lair serves as the seat of its power and a vault for its treasure. With its innate toughness and tolerance for severe environmental effects, a dragon selects or builds a lair not for shelter but for defense, favoring multiple entrances and exits, and security for its hoard.

Most chromatic dragon lairs are hidden in dangerous and remote locations to prevent all but the most audacious mortals from reaching them. A black dragon might lair in the heart of a vast swamp, while a red dragon might claim the caldera of an active volcano. In addition to the natural defenses of their lairs, powerful chromatic dragons use magical guardians, traps, and subservient creatures to protect their treasures.

entries.name: Queen of Evil Dragons
entries: Tiamat the Dragon Queen is the chief deity of evil dragonkind. She dwells on Avernus, the first layer of the Nine Hells. As a lesser god, Tiamat has the power to grant spells to her worshipers, though she is loath to share her power. She epitomizes the avarice of evil dragons, believing that the multiverse and all its treasures will one day be hers and hers alone.

Tiamat is a gigantic dragon whose five heads reflect the forms of the chromatic dragons that worship her-black, blue, green, red, and white. She is a terror on the battlefield, capable of annihilating whole armies with her five breath weapons, her formidable spellcasting, and her fearsome claws.

Tiamat's most hated enemy is Bahamut the Platinum Dragon, with whom she shares control of the faith of dragonkind. She also holds a special enmity for Asmodeus, who long ago stripped her of the rule of Avernus and who continues to curb the Dragon Queen's power.

True dragons are winged reptiles of ancient lineage and fearsome power. They are known and feared for their predatory cunning and greed, with the oldest dragons accounted as some of the most powerful creatures in the world. Dragons are also magical creatures whose innate power fuels their dreaded breath weapons and other preternatural abilities.

Many creatures, including wyverns and dragon turtles, have draconic blood. However, true dragons fall into the two broad categories of chromatic and metallic dragons. The black, blue, green, red, and white dragons are selfish, evil, and feared by all. The brass, bronze, copper, gold, and silver dragons are noble, good, and highly respected by the wise.

Though their goals and ideals vary tremendously, all true dragons covet wealth, hoarding mounds of coins and gathering gems, jewels, and magic items. Dragons with large hoards are loath to leave them for long, venturing out of their lairs only to patrol or feed.

True dragons pass through four distinct stages of life, from lowly wyrmlings to ancient dragons, which can live for over a thousand years. In that time, their might can become unrivaled and their hoards can grow beyond price.
Dragon Age Categories

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Magma erupts from a point on the ground the dragon can see within 120 feet of it, creating a 20-foot-high, 5-foot-radius geyser. Each creature in the geyser's area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A tremor shakes the lair in a 60-foot radius around the dragon. Each creature other than the dragon on the ground in that area must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

Volcanic gases form a cloud in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is lightly obscured. It lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round. Each creature that starts its turn in the cloud must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its turn. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creature is {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Additional Lair Actions
entries: At your discretion, a legendary ({@creature Adult Red Dragon||adult} or {@creature Ancient Red Dragon||ancient}) red dragon can use one or both of the following additional lair actions while in its lair:

items.name: Noxious Smoke
items.entry: A cloud of thick, dark smoke fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is {@book heavily obscured|PHB|8|Vision and Light}. A creature other than the dragon that starts its turn in the cloud or enters it for the first time on its turn must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its turn. The cloud lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

items.name: Searing Heat
items.entry: Searing heat spreads out in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Any creature that enters the affected area or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The heat lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a legendary red dragon's lair is warped by the dragon's magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Small earthquakes are common within 6 miles of the dragon's lair.
Water sources within 1 mile of the lair are supernaturally warm and tainted by sulfur.
Rocky fissures within 1 mile of the dragon's lair form portals to the Elemental Plane of Fire, allowing creatures of elemental fire into the world to dwell nearby.

entries: If the dragon dies, these effects fade over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

entries.name: Additional Regional Effects
entries: Any of these effects might appear in the area around a red dragon's lair, in addition to or instead of the effects described in the {@i Monster Manual}:

items.name: Desertification
items.entry: Precipitation is almost nonexistent within 6 miles of the dragon's lair, making the land parched and arid and most plant life withered and brown.

items.name: Fiery Senses
items.entry: The dragon can hear up to 30 feet through any open flame within 1 mile of the dragon's lair.

items.name: Ominous Flames
items.entry: Open flames within 6 miles of the dragon's lair are tinged dark red, hiss and crackle constantly, and throw off embers and showers of sparks.

bonus.name: Melting Heat (Concentration) {@recharge}
entries: The dragon begins emitting intense enough heat that can even make creatures unaccustomed to such environments feint. For the next minute, or until the dragon's concentration is broken (as if concentrating on a spell), any creature that starts its turn within 15 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw, or take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage. A creature that fails its saving throw by 5 or more also gains a level of {@condition exhaustion}, while a creature that fails its saving throw by 10 or more falls {@condition unconscious} until the start of its next turn if it has at least 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}.

bonus.name: Tail {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

bonus.name: Stomp {@recharge 4}
entries: The dragon stomps on a Large or smaller creature within 5 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, or it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage and it is knocked {@condition prone}. As long as the dragon remains on top of it, it is {@condition restrained} and it can't breathe unless it uses its action to succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength check and free itself. At the end of each of its turns, a {@condition restrained} creature takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Stomp
entries: When a creature misses with a melee attack against the dragon, the dragon can use its reaction to stomp it into the ground. The dragon uses its Stomp against the attacker if it is within range.

reaction.name: Fiery Nostrils
entries: When a creature targets the dragon with a melee attack, it can release a fiery plume from its nostrils. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, or take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage. On a failure, the creature also automatically misses with its attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Draconic Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Draconic Presence
entries: The dragon uses one of the following auras.

items.name: Frightful Presence
items.entry: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

items.name: Tyrant's Presence
items.entry: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw or come under the effects of the command spell. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Tyrant's Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 56 ({@damage 16d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. If it detects a creature that was previously hidden, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack. On a hit, the dragon can expend an additional legendary action to deal an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage with the attack, and ignite the target. At the end of each of its turns, the target must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage on a failure. On a success the effect ends.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

entries: You can customize any dragon's stat block to reflect the dragon's unique character. Minor changes such as those below are easy to make and have no impact on a dragon's challenge rating.

entries: Most dragons prefer to speak Draconic but learn Common for dealing with allies and minions. But given their high Intelligence and long life span, dragons can easily learn additional languages. You can add languages to a dragon's stat block.

entries: Most dragons are proficient in the {@skill Perception} and {@skill Stealth} skills, and many dragons have additional skill proficiencies. As with languages, you can customize a dragon's skill list (even doubling their proficiency bonus with certain skills) to reflect particular interests and activities. You can also give a dragon tool proficiencies, particularly if the dragon spends time in Humanoid form.

entries: {@note See the "Variant: Dragons as Innate Spellcasters" inset(s), below.}

Whenever the dragon is subjected to fire damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the fire damage dealt.

The dragon doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

The dragon can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

entries: You might decide that dragons in your campaign, being an essential part of the Material Plane, are nearly impossible to destroy. A dragon's life essence might be preserved in the egg from which it first emerged, in its hoard, or in a cavernous hall at the center of the world, just as a lich's essence is hidden in a phylactery.

If it has an essence-preserving object, a destroyed dragon gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the object.

items.name: Special Senses
entries: Most dragons have {@sense blindsight} and {@sense darkvision}. You might upgrade {@sense blindsight} to {@sense truesight}, or you could give a dragon with a burrowing speed {@sense tremorsense}.

fluff.name: Adult Red Dragon

entries: The most covetous of the true dragons, red dragons tirelessly seek to increase their treasure hoards. They are exceptionally vain, even for dragons, and their conceit is reflected in their proud bearing and their disdain for other creatures. The odor of sulfur and pumice surrounds a red dragon, whose swept-back horns and spinal frill define its silhouette. Its beaked snout vents smoke at all times, and its eyes dance with flame when it is angry. Its wings are the longest of any chromatic dragon, and have a blue-black tint along the trailing edge that resembles metal burned blue by fire.

The scales of a red dragon wyrmling are a bright glossy scarlet, turning a dull, deeper red and becoming as thick and strong as metal as the dragon ages. Its pupils also fade as it ages, and the oldest red dragons have eyes that resemble molten lava orbs.

entries.name: Mountain Masters
entries: Red dragons prefer mountainous terrain, badlands, and any other locale where they can perch high and survey their domain. Their preference for mountains brings them into conflict with the hill-dwelling copper dragons from time to time.

entries.name: Arrogant Tyrants
entries: Red dragons fly into destructive rages and act on impulse when angered. They are so ferocious and vengeful that they are regarded as the archetypical evil dragon by many cultures.

No other dragon comes close to the arrogance of the red dragon. These creatures see themselves as kings and emperors, and view the rest of dragonkind as inferior. Believing that they are chosen by Tiamat to rule in her name, red dragons consider the world and every creature in it as theirs to command.

entries.name: Status and Slaves
entries: Red dragons are fiercely territorial and isolationist. However, they yearn to know about events in the wider world, and they make use of lesser creatures as informants, messengers, and spies. They are most interested in news about other red dragons, with which they compete constantly for status.

When it requires servants, a red dragon demands fealty from chaotic evil humanoids. If allegiance isn't forthcoming, it slaughters a tribe's leaders and claims lordship over the survivors. Creatures serving a red dragon live in constant terror of being roasted and eaten for displeasing it. They spend most of their time fawning over the creature in an attempt to stay alive.

entries.name: Obsessive Collectors
entries: Red dragons value wealth above all else, and their treasure hoards are legendary. They covet anything of monetary value, and can often judge the worth of a bauble to within a copper piece at a glance. A red dragon has a special affection for treasure claimed from powerful enemies it has slain, exhibiting that treasure to prove its superiority.

A red dragon knows the value and provenance of every item in its hoard, along with each item's exact location. It might notice the absence of a single coin, igniting its rage as it tracks down and slays the thief without mercy. If the thief can't be found, the dragon goes on a rampage, laying waste to towns and villages in an attempt to sate its wrath.

entries.name: A Red Dragon's Lair
entries: Red dragons lair in high mountains or hills, dwelling in caverns under snow-capped peaks, or within the deep halls of abandoned mines and dwarven strongholds. Caves with volcanic or geothermal activity are the most highly prized red dragon lairs, creating hazards that hinder intruders and letting searing heat and volcanic gases wash over a dragon as it sleeps. With its hoard well protected deep within the lair, a red dragon spends as much of its time outside the mountain as in it. For a red dragon, the great heights of the world are the throne from which it can look out to survey all it controls-and the wider world it seeks to control.
Throughout the lair complex, servants erect monuments to the dragon's power, telling the grim story of its life, the enemies it has slain, and the nations it has conquered.

entries.name: Chromatic Dragons
entries: The black, blue, green, red, and white dragons represent the evil side of dragonkind. Aggressive, gluttonous, and vain, chromatic dragons are dark sages and powerful tyrants feared by all creatures-including each other.

entries.name: Driven by Greed
entries: Chromatic dragons lust after treasure, and this greed colors their every scheme and plot. They believe that the world's wealth belongs to them by right, and a chromatic dragon seizes that wealth without regard for the humanoids and other creatures that have "stolen" it. With its piles of coins, gleaming gems, and magic items, a dragon's hoard is the stuff of legend. However, chromatic dragons have no interest in commerce, amassing wealth for no other reason than to have it.

entries.name: Creatures of Ego
entries: Chromatic dragons are united by their sense of superiority, believing themselves the most powerful and worthy of all mortal creatures. When they interact with other creatures, it is only to further their own interests. They believe in their innate right to rule, and this belief is the cornerstone of every chromatic dragon's personality and worldview. Trying to humble a chromatic dragon is like trying to convince the wind to stop blowing. To these creatures, humanoids are animals, fit to serve as prey or beasts of burden, and wholly unworthy of respect.

entries.name: Dangerous Lairs
entries: A dragon's lair serves as the seat of its power and a vault for its treasure. With its innate toughness and tolerance for severe environmental effects, a dragon selects or builds a lair not for shelter but for defense, favoring multiple entrances and exits, and security for its hoard.

Most chromatic dragon lairs are hidden in dangerous and remote locations to prevent all but the most audacious mortals from reaching them. A black dragon might lair in the heart of a vast swamp, while a red dragon might claim the caldera of an active volcano. In addition to the natural defenses of their lairs, powerful chromatic dragons use magical guardians, traps, and subservient creatures to protect their treasures.

entries.name: Queen of Evil Dragons
entries: Tiamat the Dragon Queen is the chief deity of evil dragonkind. She dwells on Avernus, the first layer of the Nine Hells. As a lesser god, Tiamat has the power to grant spells to her worshipers, though she is loath to share her power. She epitomizes the avarice of evil dragons, believing that the multiverse and all its treasures will one day be hers and hers alone.

Tiamat is a gigantic dragon whose five heads reflect the forms of the chromatic dragons that worship her-black, blue, green, red, and white. She is a terror on the battlefield, capable of annihilating whole armies with her five breath weapons, her formidable spellcasting, and her fearsome claws.

Tiamat's most hated enemy is Bahamut the Platinum Dragon, with whom she shares control of the faith of dragonkind. She also holds a special enmity for Asmodeus, who long ago stripped her of the rule of Avernus and who continues to curb the Dragon Queen's power.

True dragons are winged reptiles of ancient lineage and fearsome power. They are known and feared for their predatory cunning and greed, with the oldest dragons accounted as some of the most powerful creatures in the world. Dragons are also magical creatures whose innate power fuels their dreaded breath weapons and other preternatural abilities.

Many creatures, including wyverns and dragon turtles, have draconic blood. However, true dragons fall into the two broad categories of chromatic and metallic dragons. The black, blue, green, red, and white dragons are selfish, evil, and feared by all. The brass, bronze, copper, gold, and silver dragons are noble, good, and highly respected by the wise.

Though their goals and ideals vary tremendously, all true dragons covet wealth, hoarding mounds of coins and gathering gems, jewels, and magic items. Dragons with large hoards are loath to leave them for long, venturing out of their lairs only to patrol or feed.

True dragons pass through four distinct stages of life, from lowly wyrmlings to ancient dragons, which can live for over a thousand years. In that time, their might can become unrivaled and their hoards can grow beyond price.
Dragon Age Categories

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Magma erupts from a point on the ground the dragon can see within 120 feet of it, creating a 20-foot-high, 5-foot-radius geyser. Each creature in the geyser's area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A tremor shakes the lair in a 60-foot radius around the dragon. Each creature other than the dragon on the ground in that area must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

Volcanic gases form a cloud in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is lightly obscured. It lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round. Each creature that starts its turn in the cloud must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its turn. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creature is {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Additional Lair Actions
entries: At your discretion, a legendary ({@creature Adult Red Dragon||adult} or {@creature Ancient Red Dragon||ancient}) red dragon can use one or both of the following additional lair actions while in its lair:

items.name: Noxious Smoke
items.entry: A cloud of thick, dark smoke fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is {@book heavily obscured|PHB|8|Vision and Light}. A creature other than the dragon that starts its turn in the cloud or enters it for the first time on its turn must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its turn. The cloud lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

items.name: Searing Heat
items.entry: Searing heat spreads out in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Any creature that enters the affected area or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The heat lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a legendary red dragon's lair is warped by the dragon's magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Small earthquakes are common within 6 miles of the dragon's lair.
Water sources within 1 mile of the lair are supernaturally warm and tainted by sulfur.
Rocky fissures within 1 mile of the dragon's lair form portals to the Elemental Plane of Fire, allowing creatures of elemental fire into the world to dwell nearby.

entries: If the dragon dies, these effects fade over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

entries.name: Additional Regional Effects
entries: Any of these effects might appear in the area around a red dragon's lair, in addition to or instead of the effects described in the {@i Monster Manual}:

items.name: Desertification
items.entry: Precipitation is almost nonexistent within 6 miles of the dragon's lair, making the land parched and arid and most plant life withered and brown.

items.name: Fiery Senses
items.entry: The dragon can hear up to 30 feet through any open flame within 1 mile of the dragon's lair.

items.name: Ominous Flames
items.entry: Open flames within 6 miles of the dragon's lair are tinged dark red, hiss and crackle constantly, and throw off embers and showers of sparks.

bonus.name: Tail {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the young red infernal dragon's darkvision.

trait.name: Devil's Claws
entries: When the young red infernal dragon reduces a creature to 0 hit points, it gains 10 temporary hit points and that creature has disadvantage on death saving throws while it remains at 0 hit points.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The githyanki makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire or psychic damage.

The githyanki plunder countless worlds from the decks of their astral vessels and the backs of red dragons. Feathers, beads, gems, and precious metals decorate their armor and weapons-the legendary silver swords with which they cut through their foes. Since winning their freedom from the mind flayers, the githyanki have become ruthless conquerors under the rulership of their dread lich-queen, Vlaakith.

entries.name: Astral Raiders
entries: The githyanki despise all other races, undertaking devastating raids that take them from their strongholds in the Astral Plane to the far flung corners of the multiverse. War is the ultimate expression of githyanki culture, and their pitiless black eyes know no mercy. After a raid, they leave shattered survivors enough food and resources to weakly endure. Later, the githyanki return to their conquered foes, plundering them again and again.

entries.name: Followers of Gith
entries: In their own language, githyanki means "followers of Gith." Under the guidance of Gith, the githyanki stratified into a militaristic society, with a strict caste system, dedicated to the ongoing fight against the victims and sworn enemies of their race. When their leader Gith perished, she was replaced by her undead adviser, Vlaakith. The lich-queen forbade worship of all beings except herself.

Of all their enemies, the githyanki most hate their former masters, the mind flayers. Their close kin, the githzerai, are second in their enmity. All other creatures are treated with simple contempt by the githyanki, whose xenophobic pride defines their view of inferior races.

entries.name: Silver Swords
entries: In ancient times, gith knights created special weapons to combat their mind flayer masters.

These silver swords channel the force of the wielder's will, dealing psychic as well as physical damage. A githyanki can't become a knight until it masters the singular discipline needed to will such a blade into existence. A silver sword is equivalent to a greatsword, and takes on the properties of a +3 greatsword in the hands of its creator.

In the eyes of the githyanki, each silver sword is a priceless relic and a work of art. Githyanki knights will hunt down and destroy any non-githyanki that dares to carry or wield a silver sword, reclaiming it for their people.

entries.name: Red Dragon Riders
entries: In the uprising against the illithids, Gith sought allies. Her adviser Vlaakith appealed to Tiamat, the goddess of evil dragonkind, and Gith ventured into the Nine Hells to meet with her. Only Tiamat now knows what passed between them, but Vlaakith returned to the Astral Plane with the Dragon Queen's red dragon consort Ephelomon, who proclaimed that his kind would forever act as allies to the githyanki. Not all red dragons honor the alliance kindled so long ago, but most at least don't consider the githyanki their enemies.

entries.name: Outposts in the Mortal Realm
entries: Since creatures that dwell on the Astral Plane don't age, the githyanki establish creches in remote areas of the Material Plane to raise their young. Doubling as military academies, these creches train young githyanki to harness their psychic and combat abilities. When a githyanki grows to adulthood and slays a mind flayer as part of a sacred rite of passage, it is permitted to rejoin its people on the Astral Plane.

entries.name: Gith
entries: The warlike githyanki and the contemplative githzerai are a sundered people-two cultures that utterly despise one another. Before there were githyanki or githzerai, these creatures were a single race enslaved by the mind flayers. Although they attempted to overthrow their masters many times, their rebellions were repeatedly crushed until a great leader named Gith arose.
After much bloodshed, Gith and her followers threw off the yoke of their illithid masters, but another leader named Zerthimon emerged in the aftermath of battle.

Zerthimon challenged Gith's motives, claiming that her strict martial leadership and desire for vengeance amounted to little more than another form of slavery for her people. A rift erupted between followers of each leader, and they eventually became the two races whose enmity endures to this day.

Whether these tall, gaunt creatures were peaceful or savage, cultured or primitive before the mind flayers enslaved and changed them, none can say. Not even the original name of their race remains from that distant time.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the githyanki warrior's darkvision.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki casts one of the following spells, requiring no spell components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}):

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The githyanki makes three Longsword or Telekinetic Bolt attacks, or it makes one of those attacks and uses Spellcasting.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands, plus 22 ({@damage 5d8}) fire or psychic damage.

action.name: Telekinetic Bolt
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 7} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 8d6}) force damage.

bonus.name: Astral Step {@recharge 4}
entries: The githyanki teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.
Gish blend their magical abilities with swordplay to become dangerous foes in battle. Their specialized capabilities make them well suited for assassination, raiding, and espionage.

entries.name: Githyanki
entries: Githyanki descend from an ancient people who were also the progenitors of githzerai (also in this book). These tall, gaunt folk have potent psionic powers and dwell, for the most part, on the Astral Plane. Among the best-known githyanki are the bellicose followers of the Lich Queen Vlaakith. They terrorize the Astral Plane, raiding into other planes to plunder the multiverse of its magic and riches.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the infernal githyanki gish's darkvision.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The commander casts one of the following spells, requiring no spell components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}):

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The commander makes two attacks.

action.name: Infernal Scythe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 17 ({@damage 5d6}) fire damage. On a critical hit, the target is also knocked {@condition prone} and any creatures of the commander's choice within 5 feet of the target take 17 ({@damage 5d6}) fire damage on failed {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, or half as much on a successful one.

action.name: Fire Bolt
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 9} to hit, range 120/300 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d10}) fire damage. On a critical hit, a creature is set on fire for 1 minute. At the start of each of its turns, the creature takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage. It can make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If the target takes cold damage, it has advantage on the next saving throw it makes to end this effect.

action.name: Teleport
entries: The commander teleports, along with any equipment he is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space he can see. The commander can take up to willing two creatures within it when it teleports.

bonus.name: Infernal Smite {@recharge 5}
entries: When the commander hits a creature with an attack, it can empower the attack with infernal power. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage, or half as much damage on a success. On a failure, a creature is also surrounded by hellish flames until the commander recharges this ability. If the target willingly moves 5 or more feet before then, it takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The commander adds 5 to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the commander must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

legendary.name: Command Ally
entries: The commander targets one ally it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see or hear the commander, the target can make one melee weapon attack using its reaction, if available, and has advantage on the attack roll.

legendary.name: Attack (2 Actions)
entries: The commander makes one attack.

legendary.name: Teleport (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The commander uses its teleport action.
Supreme commanders lead armies, each one commanding ten kith'raks, who in turn lead the rest of their forces. Most supreme commanders ride {@creature adult red dragon||red dragons} into battle.

entries.name: Githyanki
entries: Githyanki descend from an ancient people who were also the progenitors of githzerai (also in this book). These tall, gaunt folk have potent psionic powers and dwell, for the most part, on the Astral Plane. Among the best-known githyanki are the bellicose followers of the Lich Queen Vlaakith. They terrorize the Astral Plane, raiding into other planes to plunder the multiverse of its magic and riches.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The infernal fleet commander has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Celestial Aura
entries: The paladin and any allies within 30 feet of them have advantage on all saving throws and are immune to the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions. Additionally, affected creatures gain 10 temporary hit points if they begin their turn inside the aura.
If the paladin takes 25 or more necrotic damage from a single source, the aura becomes deactivated for 1 round. The aura also can't be active if the paladin is {@condition incapacitated}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The paladin's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}). They can cast the following spells without requiring any material components:

bonus.name: Surge of Vitality {@recharge 5}
entries: The paladin uses its bonus action to cause a creature it can see within 30 feet of it to regain 14 ({@dice 4d6}) hit points.

bonus.name: Radiant Shield {@recharge 5}
entries: The paladin raises his shield. One creature they can see within 30 feet of them gains a +2 bonus to its AC and sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius until the start of the paladin's next turn. A creature that hits the target with a melee attack while the shield is active, it takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) radiant damage once per turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The paladin makes two attacks with their longsword.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) slashing damage, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Burst of Light {@recharge 5}
entries: The paladin emits a burst of light from their shield in a 60-foot cone. Any creatures within the area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) radiant damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. On a failed save, a creature is also {@condition blinded} for 1 minute or until it succeeds on a repeated saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The paladin makes a longsword attack. On a hit, the paladin can expend an additional legendary action to cause the creature to become {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The paladin moves up to its speed. A creature that makes an attack of opportunity against them takes 10 radiant damage.

legendary.name: Greater Restoration (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The paladin or a willing creature it touches gains the effects of the greater restoration spell.

trait.name: Harbringer of Doom
entries: Whenever a creature within 20 feet of the angel takes damage, it takes an extra 10 damage if the angel isn't {@condition incapacitated}. Additionally, the grinning angel has advantage on attack rolls against creatures that have at least one failed death saving throw. It can perceive the presence of these creatures unerringly within 1 mile of it.
Variant: Creatures within 1 mile of the grinning angel have disadvantage on death saving throws.

trait.name: Inevitable Defeat
entries: When an attack misses the grinning angel, the attacker takes 5 psychic damage and the Angel's AC increases by 1. The angel's AC resets at the end of each of its turns.

trait.name: Powerful Presence
entries: The grinning angel can't be moved or teleported against its will, and it is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form. It also can't be affected or detected by spells of 6th level or lower unless it wishes to be. It has advantage on saving throws against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Debilitating Aura
entries: At the start of the grinning angel's turn, any creatures within 20 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw, or take {@damage 5d8} psychic damage.

If a creature fails its save by 5 or more ({@dc 15}), it becomes {@condition frightened} of the angel until targeted by a spell such as lesser restoration. If a creature fails its save by 10 or more ({@dc 10}), it becomes {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. If a creature rolls below that, it is also {@condition paralyzed} while it is {@condition frightened}.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The grinning angel's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 20}). It can cast the following spells without requiring any components:

action.name: Angelic Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}The target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution or Charisma saving throw, or gain a failed death saving throw, even while it is conscious. A creature that has a failed death saving throw in this way must repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns until it reaches 3 successes or 3 failures. If it reaches 3 failures, it dies. If it reaches 3 successes, the effect for it ends.

bonus.name: Teleport
entries: The grinning angel teleports to an unoccupied place it can see within 60 feet of it.

ac.special: 11 + the level of the spell (natural armor)

trait.name: Deprive Life (Nihilistic Only)
entries: Creatures within 5 feet of the void spirit can't regain hit points. Also, at the start of each of the void spirit's turns, each creature within 5 feet of the void spirit must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or take {@damage 3d6} necrotic damage.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The elemental can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The void spirit makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Dark Contact (Nihilistic Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} Roll {@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel}. The target loses that many hit points and has its maximum hit points reduced by an equal amount.

action.name: Mind-Reeling Contact (Boundless Only)
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft., one creature. {@h}{@damage 1d8 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} psychic damage.

reaction.name: Overpower Mind (Boundless Only)
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of the void spirit makes an Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma saving throw, the spirit can use its reaction to impose disadvantage on that save.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The being of impossibilities can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Impossible Target
entries: When the being of impossibilities would be targeted or affected by a spell or magical effect, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 4-6, it is unaffected. On a roll of 6, a wild magic surge occurs.

trait.name: Shroud of Impossibilities
entries: The being of impossibilities appears to shift in and out of existence, a living paradox. When a creature starts its turn and it can see the being of impossibilities, it must make a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, it takes 10 psychic damage. If it scores 10 or lower, it takes 15 damage and it is {@condition blinded} until the start of its next turn. If a creature scores 5 or lower, it takes 20 damage and it is {@condition incapacitated} until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Reality In Flux
entries: When a creature takes damage by the being of impossibilities, it has disadvantage on any checks it makes to maintain concentration on a spell as a result of taking that damage.

action.name: Impossible Pulse
entries: The being of impossibilities lets out a pulse of energy in a 10-foot radius around it. Any creatures in the area must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) force damage on a failure, or half as much damage on a success. The being then teleports to an unoccupied space within 60 feet of it.
When the impossible being takes this action, roll {@dice 1d3}. It must use this action a number of times equal to the roll.

action.name: Scatter {@recharge 5}
entries: The being of impossibilities targets up to 5 creatures it can see within 120 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or be teleported to an unoccupied space the being can see within 120 feet of it. On a failed save, a creature also takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) force damage, or half as much damage on a success.

action.name: Occupy (1/day)
entries: The being of impossibilities attempts to occupy the space of another creature's body within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw, or the being becomes attached to them until it becomes {@condition incapacitated} or the target dies. While the being is attached to the target, it moves with the target, and any time an attack against it misses, it hits the occupied creature instead, if it would surpass its AC. When the being's impossible target trait would cause it to be unaffected by a spell or magical effect, the occupied target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) force damage. The occupied creature takes the same damage at the end of each of its turns.
To end the occupation, the target needs to be targeted by the dispel evil and good spell, or similar magic.

bonus.name: Mental Prison (1/day)
entries: The being of impossibilities casts mental prison ({@dc 18}).

legendary.name: Impossible Pulse
entries: The being of impossibilities makes one use of its Impossible Pulse action.

legendary.name: Reverse Gravity (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Gravity is reversed in a 50-foot radius, 100-foot high cylinder centered on the being of impossibilities. This cylinder moves with the being when it moves. All creatures and objects that aren't somehow anchored to the ground in the area fall upward and reach the top of the area when you cast this spell. A creature can make a Dexterity saving throw to grab onto a fixed object it can reach, thus avoiding the fall. The effect lasts for 1 round.

legendary.name: Break Belief (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The being targets a creature it can see within 60 feet of it, showing it dizzying impossibilities. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Intelligence saving throw, or lose concentration on any spells it is maintaining. The creature then can't concentrate on any spells or effects until it completes a long rest or is affected by a spell such as lesser restoration.

from: 17 while another creature is within 30 feet

trait.name: Avoidant
entries: The deterrent's movement speed can be reduced only through magical means. The deterrent has advantage on checks made to end effects that affect its movement speed.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The deterrent has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects. When the deterrent succeeds on such a saving throw, it gains 10 temporary hit points.

trait.name: Aura of Deterrence
entries: When a creature within 30 feet of the deterrent misses with an attack, the creature takes damage as if it would have been hit by that attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deterrent makes two psychic lash attacks. If both hit a single target, it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn, and the deterrent can pull it up to 25 feet towards it if it wishes.

action.name: Psychic Lash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Deterrent Sphere (1/day)
entries: The deterrent casts otiluke's resilent sphere without requiring any components. The save for the spell is Charisma instead of Dexterity, and if a creature inside the sphere does anything during its turn except stay still and inactive, it takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) psychic damage at the end of each of its turns.

bonus.name: Protective Shade {@recharge 5}
entries: The deterrent emits an aura of protection. Any creatures of its choice within 30 feet of it gains 10 temporary hit points. If a creature is within 5 feet of an enemy, it gains twice as many temporary hit points.
If the deterrent takes this action while an enemy creature is within 5 feet of it, it provokes attacks of opportunity.

bonus.name: Armor of Deterrecne (1/day)
entries: The deterrent casts armor of agathys at 5th level without requiring any material components. The damage dealt by the spell is psychic instead of cold. If an enemy creature is within 5 feet of the deterrent when it casts this spell, it takes damage as if it had hit the deterrent with an attack.

trait.name: Reactive Punishment
entries: When a creature within 10 feet of the punisher hits a creature with an attack, the punisher can make a cleave attack against it without using a reaction.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The punisher is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form or move or teleport it against its will.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The punisher makes four cleave attacks. When an attack hits, the punisher makes its next attack with advantage if the punisher attacks a different creature than the previous one.

action.name: Cleave
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Indiscriminate Punishment
entries: When an allied creature within 30 feet of the punisher dies, a random enemy creature that could see the ally die must succceed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage on a failure, or half as much damage on a success.

legendary.name: Shove
entries: The punisher makes a shove attack against a creature within 10 feet of it.

legendary.name: Bounty Call (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The punisher designates a creature it can see. Until the end of its next turn, it takes half as much damage from that creature, but during its turn, the punisher must target that creature with its attacks if it is within range.

legendary.name: Bullrush (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The punisher rushes 30 feet straight forward in a direction of its choice. Any creatures within its path, or within 5 feet of it when it ends its movement, must succeed on a Strength saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked off balance.

reaction.name: Redeeming Glance
entries: When an ally within 30 feet of the redeemer misses with an attack, the redeemer can use its reaction to allow that creature to reroll its attack once and take the new result. On a hit, the creature can add a {@dice 2d6} to the damage roll, and gain an equal number of temporary hit points. On a hit, the redeemer also instantly regains use of its reaction.

action.name: Potent Defense
entries: The redeemer curls in a defensive posture, letting scales spread over its skin. It takes the dodge action, and its AC increases by 5 until the start of its next turn. In addition, any ally that stands within 5 feet of the redeemer also gains that bonus to its AC while it remains there. The redeemer can't take this action if it has moved during its turn, and its speed is reduced to 0 while under its effects.

action.name: Aura of Fortification {@recharge 5}
entries: The redeemer sheds an aura of fortification in a 30-foot radius from it. Roll {@dice 6d4}. Any allies in the area gain temporary hit points equal to the roll. In addition, for each 6 the redeemer rolls, it can allow an ally within range to use its reaction in order to make an attack.

action.name: Bless (1/day)
entries: The redeemer casts bless at 4th level.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The redeemer has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The apathetic makes three attacks with its unarmed strike. If the apathetic hits a target with all three attacks, the target is {@condition stunned} until the end of the apathetic's next turn.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Pain Apathy
entries: When the apathetic takes damage from a creature, roll a {@dice d6}.
1-4. This trait doesn't function until the start of the apathetic's next turn.
5. The apathetic reduces the damage taken by half.
6. The apathetic doesn't take any damage.

trait.name: Control of Fear
entries: The apathetic takes no damage from attacks or spells cast by {@condition frightened} creatures, and it has advantage on attack rolls against {@condition frightened} creatures.

reaction.name: Apathy's Fear {@recharge 5}
entries: When the apathetic hits a target with an attack, or is hit by a melee attack by a creature that isn't a construct or an undead, it can force the creature to make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature is {@condition frightened} of the apathetic for 1 minute, or until it succeeds on a repeated saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

bonus.name: Apathetic Steps
entries: The apathetic can take the disengage or dash action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hollow has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects, including effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Soul Drain
entries: When the hollow reduces a creature to 0 hit points, any creatures within 30 feet of the creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) necrotic damage and suffer the effects of the slow spell until the end of their next turn.
In addition, the hollow gains an equal amount of temporary hit points and it can move up to its speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

trait.name: Chill and Shadow
entries: At the start of its turn, the hollow can choose whether to imbue its blade with shadowy or chill energy. This affects the type of the extra damage it deals with its hollow blade (included in the attack), the effects of its Nether Infusion bonus action, and what reactions it can take.

bonus.name: Nether Infusion {@recharge 5}
entries: When the hollow hits a creature with a weapon attack, it can make its weapon reverberate with cold energy. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the target takes an extra 16 ({@damage 3d10}) cold or necrotic damage. On a success, the target takes half as much damage.

On a failure, the target is also unable to regain any hit points until the end of the hollow's next turn (Chill) or its maximum hit points are reduced by an amount equal to the extra damage dealt (Shadow).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hollow makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Hollow Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) damage, plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) necrotic or cold damage. If the attack deals cold damage, the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn, while if the attack deals necrotic damage, the hollow regains a number of hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The hollow turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell. It remains {@condition invisible} only while it is under dim light or darkness. If it is ever under bright light, the effect ends.

reaction.name: Cold Shroud (Chill)
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of the hollow targets it with an attack, the hollow can use its reaction to impose disadvantage on the roll if its blade is infused with chill energy. If the attack misses, the target's speed is reduced to 0 for the rest of its turn.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The deep siren has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The deep siren can breathe air and water.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The siren's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The siren makes one claw attack and one stupefying touch attack.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage, and the target has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes.

action.name: Stupefying Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Siren's Song
entries: The siren begins singing. Any creatures within 30 feet of it that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by the siren. While {@condition charmed}, the creatures must use their whole turn to follow the siren wherever she goes. The effect lasts until dispelled ({@dc 15}). If a {@condition charmed} creature takes damage, it can repeat the Wisdom saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

ac.special: 11 + the level of the spell (natural armor)

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The time spirit can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Temporal Field
entries: The time spirit emits a temporal field in a 10-foot radius around it. The time spirit can choose what creatures to affect with this field. When a creature enters the field for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer the effects of the slow spell until the start of its next turn, or until it is no longer in the temporal field.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The time spirit makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Time's Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} Roll {@damage 1d6 + 4 + summonSpellLevel}. The target ages by a number of days equal to the damage it takes.

trait.name: Consumption
entries: When the mouthclaw reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a mouthclaw attack, it begins consuming it. The creature becomes {@condition restrained} in the mouthclaw's mouth, and takes {@damage 3d8} acid damage at the start of each of the mouthclaw's turns. When the creature dies, the mouthclaw fully digests it, absorbing all of its memories and knowledge in the process. Another creature can pull the target out of the mouth by using its action to succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics) check.

trait.name: Magic-Resistant Carapace
entries: Spell attack rolls against the mouthclaw are made with disadvantage. On a hit, the mouthclaw takes half as much damage from them.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mouthclaw makes two mouthclaw attacks.

action.name: Mouthclaw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

The mouthclaws are an aberrant species born long ago by a magocracy that sought to discover a species that would not only be the apex predator in any environment, but would also fit and thrive in any circumstance. After a number of centuries, the experiment run amok, and the mouthclaw was created: a species with the unique ability to consume a creature's memories and knowledge, and the hardiness to survive long enough stretches of time in order to make use of it.

No one clearly knows the intelligence level that the mouthclaws have acquired, since they seem to have no intention of communicating if they are able to speak language, but their behavior and planning seems to be highly capable.

Frightened of their capacity to take over any territory, the magocracy sealed the mouthclaws away in the patch of the land that they had up until then spread to, forbidding any passage in or out for centuries.

The magocracy has long since perished, and the protective runes have lost their old meaning to the new denizens of the lands. Believing there to be ancient tombs hiding ancient artifacts behind the ruins, adventuring parties have tampered with the seals and delved into the caverns that used to be the mouthclaw's sealed domain.
How have the mouthclaws changed throughout the centuries that have passed, and how will their first acquaintance with the new humans be?

trait.name: Consumption
entries: When the mouthclaw reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a mouthclaw attack, it begins consuming it. The creature becomes {@condition restrained} in the mouthclaw's mouth, and takes {@damage 3d8} acid damage at the start of each of the mouthclaw's turns. When the creature dies, the mouthclaw fully digests it, absorbing all of its memories and knowledge in the process. Another creature can pull the target out of the mouth by using its action to succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics) check.

trait.name: Magic-Resistant Carapace
entries: Spell attack rolls against the mouthclaw are made with disadvantage. On a hit, the mouthclaw takes half as much damage from them.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mouthclaw makes two mouthclaw attacks. It can substitute any of these attacks with a spit attack.

action.name: Mouthclaw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60/90 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) acid damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Psychic Acid Belch {@recharge 5}
entries: The mouthclaw spitter launches a torrent of psychic acid in a 30-foot cone or a line that is 5 feet wide and 90 feet long in a direction of its choice. Each creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) acid damage and 17 ({@damage 5d6}) psychic damage on failure, or half as much damage on a success.

A creature that failed its saving throw is also coated in saliva that contains the mouthclaw's pheromones. Mouthclaws have advantage on attack rolls against the creature and on ability checks made to locate or track its movements until a creature uses an action to swipe the saliva away.

The mouthclaws are an aberrant species born long ago by a magocracy that sought to discover a species that would not only be the apex predator in any environment, but would also fit and thrive in any circumstance. After a number of centuries, the experiment run amok, and the mouthclaw was created: a species with the unique ability to consume a creature's memories and knowledge, and the hardiness to survive long enough stretches of time in order to make use of it.

Believing there to be ancient tombs hiding ancient artifacts behind the ruins, adventuring parties have tampered with the seals and delved into the caverns that used to be the mouthclaw's sealed domain.
How have the mouthclaws changed throughout the centuries that have passed, and how will their first acquaintance with the new humans be?

reaction.name: Skitter
entries: When an attack against the mouthclaw misses, it can use its reaction to move up to half of its movement speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

trait.name: Consumption
entries: When the mouthclaw reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a mouthclaw attack, it begins consuming it. The creature becomes {@condition restrained} in the mouthclaw's mouth, and takes {@damage 3d8} acid damage at the start of each of the mouthclaw's turns. When the creature dies, the mouthclaw fully digests it, absorbing all of its memories and knowledge in the process. Another creature can pull the target out of the mouth by using its action to succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics) check.

trait.name: Magic-Resistant Carapace
entries: Spell attack rolls against the mouthclaw are made with disadvantage. On a hit, the mouthclaw takes half as much damage from them. Additionally, the mouthclaw has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects of 3rd level or lower.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the mouthclaw protector moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a mouthclaw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the mouthclaw protector can make one appendage lock attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mouthclaw makes two mouthclaw attacks. If both attacks hit the same target, the mouthclaw can use its charge trait against the target even if it doesn't move towards it.

action.name: Mouthclaw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Appendage Lock
entries: The mouthclaw protector tries to grapple and restrain a creature within 5 feet of it with its mouth. The target must succeed on a contented Strength (Athletics) check with the protector or become {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} by it (escape {@dc 16}). While grappling a creature in this way, the protector can only attack that creature with its attacks and it deals an additional 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage to it with its attacks. The protector can use a bonus action to release a creature from its mouth.

The mouthclaws are an aberrant species born long ago by a magocracy that sought to discover a species that would not only be the apex predator in any environment, but would also fit and thrive in any circumstance. After a number of centuries, the experiment run amok, and the mouthclaw was created: a species with the unique ability to consume a creature's memories and knowledge, and the hardiness to survive long enough stretches of time in order to make use of it.

No one clearly knows the intelligence level that the mouthclaws have acquired, since they seem to have no intention of communicating if they are able to speak language, but their behavior and planning seems to be highly capable.

Frightened of their capacity to take over any territory, the magocracy sealed the mouthclaws away in the patch of the land that they had up until then spread to, forbidding any passage in or out for centuries.

The magocracy has long since perished, and the protective runes have lost their old meaning to the new denizens of the lands. Believing there to be ancient tombs hiding ancient artifacts behind the ruins, adventuring parties have tampered with the seals and delved into the caverns that used to be the mouthclaw's sealed domain.
How have the mouthclaws changed throughout the centuries that have passed, and how will their first acquaintance with the new humans be?

reaction.name: Take the Hit
entries: When another mouthclaw that isn't a protector is hit by an attack, the protector can use its reaction to be targeted by the attack instead if both the attacker and its normal target are within 5 feet of the protector.

trait.name: Consumption
entries: When the mouthclaw reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a mouthclaw attack, it begins consuming it. The creature becomes {@condition restrained} in the mouthclaw's mouth, and takes {@damage 3d8} acid damage at the start of each of the mouthclaw's turns. When the creature dies, the mouthclaw fully digests it, absorbing all of its memories and knowledge in the process. Another creature can pull the target out of the mouth by using its action to succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics) check.

trait.name: Magic-Resistant Carapace
entries: Spell attack rolls against the mouthclaw are made with disadvantage. On a hit, the mouthclaw takes half as much damage from them. Additionally, the mouthclaw has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mouthclaw makes two mouthclaw attacks.

action.name: Mouthclaw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The mouthclaw psion's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components. If the psion consumes a creature that has the ability to cast spells, the next time the psion completes a short rest it can replace one of the spells it can cast with a spell that the creature was able to cast.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The mirroring aberration is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Mirroring Form
entries: When the mirroring aberration takes damage, it can create a copy of the opponent's means of destruction and use it for itself. When it takes damage, the mirroring aberration can switch the damage of its Mirroring Attack to the type of the damage it took until it uses this trait again. If the damage was dealt by an attack, the mirroring aberration can also copy the mode of the attack, melee or ranged, for its Mirroring Attack as well.
For example, if the mirroring aberration is hit by an arrow, it can cause its mirroring attack fire back an arrow as well. The attack has the same reach, range and properties of the original attack.

trait.name: Mirror Step (1/round)
entries: At any point during a round, the mirroring aberration can steal the place of another creature, perfectly mimicking its appearance. The mirroring aberration targets a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw, or the two creatures switch places, each teleporting to the other's last position. The switch is impossible to detect with the naked eye. When the aberration appears, it can choose to take on the appearance of the target it switched places with. The mirroring aberration may do so at any time without using an action, though it may only do so once per turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The aberration makes two mirroring attacks or casts a mirrored spell.

action.name: Mirroring Attack
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach ? ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) damage of the type determined by Mirroring Form.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mirroring aberration's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells without requiring any components:

reaction.name: Mirrored Spell (1/day)
entries: When the mirrored aberration is targeted or affected by a spell, it can use its reaction to imprint the arcane form in its memory. Until the end of its next turn, the aberration can cast the spell once using its own spellcasting ability. The spell must be of 3rd level or lower.
